description: Current version does not allow adding new folders, does not show folders expected

Many thanks for your extension. Unfortunately, it does work work for me. 
1/ As previously noted by Albert, it does not read the wallpapers found in /usr/share/backgrounds/gnome
2/ it does manage my triple screen setup (3*1080p). Wallpapers are overlapping, are not scaling.
summary: Does not work as intended with triple screen

description: I have used this app in the past w/o any problems. but the flatpak version on the latest Gnome desktop environment is nor working~!!
Works very well, but did give me errors when I deleted folders it was expecting wallpapers in. So you gotta be careful and remove them from this software before deleting them for good.
summary: very nice for multi monitor setups on gnome

description: (y)これアップはすごいですね。本当！
unable to view any images on the added folder

GUI is simple and not over-engineered. 
I'd love this if it worked in Fedora 30 though :/ 

Good concept.
summary: I like it, but it does not work in Fedora 30

description: Works great on Fedora 31, read alot of negative reviews which made me hesitant to install but because of lack of more options, I decided to give it a go, and I don't regret it at all. Was a little confusing at the beginning, it asked for a folder and I was trying to directly add pictures, after I added the folder which the pictures were in they popped up right away. I did make sure the pictures were added to my main /boot drive in my /home directory to avoid any issues with loading the images from drives that must be mounted during boot.

Thank you for this. I have spent years trying to find something that allows different wallpapers on different monitors in Gnome. Other DEs do this by default, and it's frustrating to see because my "optimal" workflow is Gnome but I like having 1337 wallpapers lol. 

This works on Arch Linux (July 2020) and Ubuntu 20.04. Both Gnome environments. 

I have 1440p monitor and two 1080p monitors. One 1080 monitor is in landscape and the other portrait. 

App allows you to choose the monitor and assign the wallpaper. It looks like it brings up whatever is in the ~/Pictures directory by default. 

Thanks again! BEAST of an application. Survived a reboot, too.
always download this
Fair to middling, as the last person who made comment in 2018 said, you STILL cannot add new folders. Seriousely, why not? That's just ridiculous.
summary: Average, not enough attention given to the working of this app

description: Working fine for me on Ubuntu Budgie 20.20. Been waiting for this and happy i have found it

I have two monitors but 4 shows up in the settings (yea makes total sense! *cough*). Can't even make it clear which is which when clicking on it. Can't believe this is 2020 and we still have to google how to set two different backgrounds on each screen. lol. Go do some babysitting or something you linux idiots. Why do people still needs to google every little things and spends hours NOT doing actual work. Can't even make a window resize work properly after all this time. just wow
summary: what a sh*t software, just like the rest of them on unix

description: Easily lets me set a vertical wallpaper for one monitor and a horizontal wallpaper for another. Just what I needed.
Install the flathub version if you want it to work. The others did nothing for me.
summary: Flathub version works but the others don't

description:
to add new folders you need to select a path of a desired folder-1. and then you write a last folder as a file name. what a nonsense.
at the end i didn't figure out how to apply wallpapers. blue check button doesnt work.
its just useless.

Currently running version 2.0.3 on Ubuntu 18.04. Having dual monitors I was shocked that Linux didn't support different wallpapers on each monitor. So I was very relieved when I found Hydrapaper. Does almost exactly what I want. The only thing it doesn't do is to automatically change the wallpapers at a user defined time. Need to see if I can run it automatically at startup. My Linux knowledge is very limited so I assume it's either use cron or out something in .profile. So need to find executable and see if it can be run from $ prompt.
Probably 4.5 stars, the last bit would be awarded if it automatically changed the wallpapers.

Frustrated with Gnome dropping any kind of functionality with tweaking background images (span desktops, etc.), I installed this. It seems to come up, allows me to set some functions and select a desktop background image, but then nothing happens. Functionality is a mystery, leaving you randomly clicking buttons to see if something happens...
it's very strange but it doesn't work fine i was experimenting app freezing
summary: it doesn't work fine on zorin

description: The UI looks simple and nice but it does not do anything when I select the images and hit the apply button. Giving two stars since I like the idea but it should not show up in the Software center if it is not compatible or in working state.

description: Thank you for the update ! Work well over here ;)
Ability to assign a different wallpaper to each of your monitors is a must, and this app does it well.
I could use the multi desktop function.

When I opened it for the first time it was on a small screen and I couldn't understand nothing, than I maximized the window and I understood how to use it.
Anyway, neat program, but I think there is no reason to let the window shrink to a point where you can't see the wallpapers to select them.

安装麻烦些 重启后才会有图标 双屏放2个背景图 非常满足我的需求
下面的命令是从互联网中找的
sudo apt install -y flatpak
flatpak --user remote-add --if-not-exists flathub https://flathub.org/repo/flathub.flatpakrepo
flatpak --user install -y flathub org.gabmus.hydrapaper

flatpak uninstall org.gabmus.hydrapaper
更换壁纸的程序；这种功能，桌面环境已经包含了。
